newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: BOK intervenes for 5th time, sells dlrs - dealers.
newsitem.headline: BOK intervenes for 5th time, sells dlrs - dealers.

text.p: The Bank of Korea intervened again in the interbank market late on Wednesday afternoon to stop the won's fall vis-a-vis the U.S. dollar, dealers said.
They said the central bank sold dollars at 893.50 won in what they said was the bank's fifth intervention of the day.
The won immediately rebounded to 893.10 but soon retreated to 893.50 on strong dollar buying for short covering and over jitters about the impact from the Kia Group's financial crisis.
South Korean banks have decided to bail out 18 of Kia's 38 affiliates by keeping credit lines open.
Bank of Korea officials could not immediately be reached for comment.
Earlier, the bank was said to have repeatedly sold dollars both in one-year forward and spot trading, starting soon after the day's trading started.
